questions.question: An athlete starts from rest and reaches a speed of $8.2\,\text{m/s}$ in $3.5\,\text{s}$. Assuming constant acceleration, determine the distance covered during this acceleration phase.
questions.explanation: For constant acceleration, the average velocity is $(v_i + v_f)/2$. Distance $d = \frac{v_i+v_f}{2}t = \frac{0+8.2}{2}(3.5) = 4.1 \times 3.5 = 14.35\,\text{m}$.

questions.question: A car traveling at $32\,\text{m/s}$ decelerates uniformly at a rate of $4.5\,\text{m/s}^2$. How many seconds does it take for the car to reach a velocity of $10\,\text{m/s}$?
questions.explanation: Using $v_f = v_i + at$, we have $10 = 32 + (-4.5)t$. Solving: $-22 = -4.5t$, so $t = 22/4.5 \approx 4.89\,\text{s}$.

questions.question: A coin is accidentally dropped from a hot air balloon that is hovering at an altitude of $150\,\text{m}$. Calculate the velocity of the coin just as it hits the ground. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$ and neglect air resistance)
questions.explanation: Using $v^2 = 2gh$ (dropped from rest), $v = \sqrt{2gh} = \sqrt{2(9.8)(150)} = \sqrt{2940} \approx 54.2\,\text{m/s}$.

questions.question: A ball is thrown straight up from the ground with an initial speed of $26\,\text{m/s}$. Determine the total time elapsed before it is caught at a height of $1.5\,\text{m}$ above the ground on its way down. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$ and neglect air resistance)
questions.explanation: Using $y = v_0t - \frac{1}{2}gt^2$ with $y = 1.5$, $v_0 = 26$, $g = 9.8$, we get $1.5 = 26t - 4.9t^2$. Rearranging: $4.9t^2 - 26t + 1.5 = 0$. Solving the quadratic yields $t \approx 5.25\,\text{s}$ (the larger root, corresponding to the ball on its way down).

questions.question: A projectile is launched at an angle of $28^{\circ}$ above the horizontal. If the initial horizontal velocity component is measured to be $15\,\text{m/s}$, calculate the magnitude of the total initial velocity.
questions.explanation: The horizontal component is given by $v_x = v_0\cos\theta$. Thus $v_0 = v_x/\cos28^{\circ} = 15/0.8829 \approx 17.0\,\text{m/s}$.

questions.question: A stone is thrown horizontally from the edge of a $24\,\text{m}$ high cliff. It lands $38\,\text{m}$ from the base of the cliff. Calculate the initial horizontal speed of the stone. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$ and neglect air resistance)
questions.explanation: Time to fall: $t = \sqrt{2h/g} = \sqrt{48/9.8} \approx 2.21\,\text{s}$. Initial horizontal speed $v_x = \text{range}/t = 38/2.21 \approx 17.2\,\text{m/s}$.

questions.question: A tennis ball is served horizontally from a height of $2.5\,\text{m}$ with a speed of $42\,\text{m/s}$. The net is $12\,\text{m}$ away and has a height of $0.9\,\text{m}$. Determine whether the ball clears the net. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$ and neglect air resistance)
questions.explanation: Time to reach net: $t = 12/42 \approx 0.286\,\text{s}$. Vertical drop: $\Delta y = \frac{1}{2}gt^2 = 4.9(0.286)^2 \approx 0.40\,\text{m}$. Height at net $= 2.5 - 0.40 = 2.1\,\text{m}$, which is greater than $0.9\,\text{m}$. Therefore, the ball clears the net.

questions.question: A boat can travel at a speed of $3.5\,\text{m/s}$ in still water. It aims directly across a river that flows with a current of $2.0\,\text{m/s}$. Calculate the angle of the boat's resultant velocity vector relative to the downstream direction along the bank.
questions.explanation: The boat's velocity components are $3.5\,\text{m/s}$ across the river and $2.0\,\text{m/s}$ downstream. The angle relative to the downstream direction is $\theta = \tan^{-1}(v_{\text{across}}/v_{\text{downstream}}) = \tan^{-1}(3.5/2.0) \approx 60.3^{\circ}$.

questions.question: Car A moves North at $50\,\text{km/h}$ and Car B moves North at $35\,\text{km/h}$. Determine the velocity of Car B as observed from Car A (i.e., the relative velocity $\vec{v}_{B/A}$).
questions.explanation: $\vec{v}_{B/A} = \vec{v}_B - \vec{v}_A = 35\,\text{km/h North} - 50\,\text{km/h North} = -15\,\text{km/h}$ directed South. So the relative velocity is $15\,\text{km/h}$ South.

questions.question: An $18\,\text{kg}$ sled is pulled along a horizontal surface by a constant force of $55\,\text{N}$ directed horizontally. If the coefficient of kinetic friction is $0.12$, calculate the acceleration of the sled. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: Normal force $N = mg = 18(9.8) = 176.4\,\text{N}$. Frictional force $f_k = \mu_k N = 0.12(176.4) \approx 21.17\,\text{N}$. Net force $F_{\text{net}} = 55 - 21.17 = 33.83\,\text{N}$. Acceleration $a = F_{\text{net}}/m = 33.83/18 \approx 1.88\,\text{m/s}^2$.

questions.question: A $2.0\,\text{kg}$ block is sliding on a rough horizontal floor with an initial velocity of $6.0\,\text{m/s}$. If it comes to a complete stop after sliding $4.0\,\text{m}$, calculate the magnitude of the constant friction force acting on it.
questions.explanation: Using $v_f^2 = v_i^2 + 2a\Delta x$: $0 = 36 + 2a(4) \Rightarrow a = -36/8 = -4.5\,\text{m/s}^2$. The friction force provides this deceleration: $f = m|a| = 2.0(4.5) = 9.0\,\text{N}$.

questions.question: A $1400\,\text{kg}$ car accelerates from $15\,\text{m/s}$ to $25\,\text{m/s}$ in $8.0\,\text{s}$. Calculate the net force required to produce this motion, assuming a constant acceleration.
questions.explanation: Acceleration $a = \Delta v/\Delta t = (25-15)/8.0 = 10/8 = 1.25\,\text{m/s}^2$. Net force $F = ma = 1400(1.25) = 1750\,\text{N}$.

questions.question: A $4.0\,\text{kg}$ mass is placed on a ramp that is tilted at an angle of $50^{\circ}$ to the horizontal. Calculate the magnitude of the normal force exerted by the ramp on the mass. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: The normal force is $N = mg\cos\theta = 4.0(9.8)\cos50^{\circ} = 39.2(0.6428) \approx 25.2\,\text{N}$.

questions.question: A block slides down a $20^{\circ}$ incline with a constant velocity. Determine the coefficient of kinetic friction between the block and the surface of the incline. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: At constant velocity, the net force parallel to the incline is zero: $mg\sin\theta = \mu_k mg\cos\theta$. Thus $\mu_k = \tan\theta = \tan20^{\circ} \approx 0.364$.

questions.question: Two masses, $5.0\,\text{kg}$ and $9.0\,\text{kg}$, are connected by a light string that passes over a frictionless pulley. The masses are released from rest. Calculate the magnitude of the acceleration of the masses. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)

A $12\,\text{kg}$ mass rests on a frictionless horizontal table. It is connected by a string over a pulley to a $6.0\,\text{kg}$ mass that hangs freely. Calculate the tension in the string once the system is released from rest. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: Acceleration $a = m_2g/(m_1+m_2) = 6.0(9.8)/18 = 58.8/18 \approx 3.267\,\text{m/s}^2$. For the $12\,\text{kg}$ mass, the tension provides its acceleration: $T = m_1a = 12(3.267) \approx 39.2\,\text{N}$.

questions.question: An $80\,\text{kg}$ window washer is supported by a vertical cable attached to a platform. If the washer and platform are accelerating upward at $0.45\,\text{m/s}^2$, calculate the tension in the cable. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: Applying Newton's second law: $T - mg = ma$, so $T = m(g + a) = 80(9.8 + 0.45) = 80(10.25) = 820\,\text{N}$.

questions.question: A $15\,\text{kg}$ sign is suspended from a horizontal beam by two wires. Each wire makes an angle of $25^{\circ}$ with the vertical. Calculate the tension in each wire. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: The vertical components of tension support the weight: $2T\cos25^{\circ} = mg = 147\,\text{N}$. Thus $T = 147/(2\cos25^{\circ}) = 147/(2 \times 0.9063) \approx 147/1.8126 \approx 81.1\,\text{N}$.

questions.question: A point on the edge of a wheel of radius $0.30\,\text{m}$ has a centripetal acceleration of $12\,\text{m/s}^2$. Calculate the tangential speed of that point.
questions.explanation: Centripetal acceleration $a_c = v^2/r$, so $v = \sqrt{a_c r} = \sqrt{12(0.30)} = \sqrt{3.6} \approx 1.90\,\text{m/s}$.

questions.question: A vinyl record makes $33.3$ revolutions per minute (RPM). Calculate the frequency in Hertz and the period in seconds for a point on the record.
questions.explanation: Frequency $f = 33.3/60 \approx 0.555\,\text{Hz}$. Period $T = 1/f \approx 1.80\,\text{s}$.

questions.question: A $0.25\,\text{kg}$ ball is attached to a string of length $0.60\,\text{m}$ and whirled in a vertical circle. At the bottom of the circle, the speed of the ball is $5.5\,\text{m/s}$. Calculate the tension in the string at this point. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)

A $60\,\text{kg}$ rider is on a roller coaster at the top of a circular hill with a radius of $18\,\text{m}$. If the car is moving at a constant speed of $10\,\text{m/s}$, calculate the apparent weight of the rider at the top. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: At the top, the net inward force is $mg - N = mv^2/r$, where $N$ is the normal force (apparent weight). Solving: $N = mg - mv^2/r = 60(9.8 - 100/18) = 60(9.8 - 5.556) = 60(4.244) \approx 254\,\text{N}$.

questions.question: A $0.40\,\text{kg}$ mass is attached to a string and swung in a horizontal circle of radius $0.90\,\text{m}$ on a frictionless surface. If the string can withstand a maximum tension of $80\,\text{N}$, what is the maximum speed the mass can have without breaking the string?
questions.explanation: Tension provides the centripetal force: $T = mv^2/r$. Solving for $v$: $v = \sqrt{Tr/m} = \sqrt{80(0.90)/0.40} = \sqrt{72/0.40} = \sqrt{180} \approx 13.4\,\text{m/s}$.

questions.question: A highway curve is banked at an angle of $12^{\circ}$ and has a radius of $65\,\text{m}$. Calculate the speed at which a car can negotiate this curve without needing any frictional force. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: For a frictionless banked curve, $\tan\theta = v^2/(rg)$. Solving for $v$: $v = \sqrt{rg\tan\theta} = \sqrt{65(9.8)\tan12^{\circ}} = \sqrt{637 \times 0.2126} \approx \sqrt{135.4} \approx 11.6\,\text{m/s}$.

questions.question: Calculate the magnitude of the gravitational force between a $1500\,\text{kg}$ car and a $2500\,\text{kg}$ truck when their centers of mass are $5.0\,\text{m}$ apart. (Take $G = 6.67 \times 10^{-11}\,\text{N}\cdot\text{m}^2/\text{kg}^2$)
An object weighs $600\,\text{N}$ on Earth's surface. What would it weigh on a planet that has three times the mass of Earth and three times the radius of Earth?
questions.explanation: Gravitational acceleration $g = GM/R^2$. On the new planet, $g' = G(3M)/(3R)^2 = (3/9) GM/R^2 = g/3$. Therefore weight $= mg' = (mg)/3 = 600/3 = 200\,\text{N}$.

questions.question: A $12\,\text{kg}$ crate is pushed $6.0\,\text{m}$ along a horizontal floor at a constant speed by a constant force of $40\,\text{N}$ applied horizontally. Calculate the work done by the friction force during this displacement.
questions.explanation: At constant speed, the applied force equals the friction force in magnitude: $f_k = 40\,\text{N}$. The work done by friction is $W = -f_k d = -40 \times 6.0 = -240\,\text{J}$.

questions.question: A $0.20\,\text{kg}$ hockey puck is moving at $12\,\text{m/s}$. A constant force of $0.50\,\text{N}$ acts against its motion. Calculate the distance the puck slides before coming to rest.
questions.explanation: Initial kinetic energy $KE_i = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 = 0.5(0.20)(144) = 14.4\,\text{J}$. The work done by the force brings the puck to rest: $W = -Fd = -0.50d$. By work-energy theorem, $W = \Delta KE = 0 - 14.4 = -14.4\,\text{J}$. Thus $0.50d = 14.4$, so $d = 14.4/0.50 = 28.8\,\text{m}$.

questions.question: A $1200\,\text{kg}$ car is accelerated from $5.0\,\text{m/s}$ to $20\,\text{m/s}$ by a net force. Calculate the total work done on the car during this process.

A marble of mass $0.10\,\text{kg}$ is shot from a spring-loaded gun. The spring has a spring constant $k = 250\,\text{N/m}$ and is compressed by $0.06\,\text{m}$ before firing. Calculate the speed of the marble as it leaves the gun, assuming all spring potential energy converts to kinetic energy.
questions.explanation: Elastic potential energy stored: $E = \frac{1}{2}kx^2 = 0.5(250)(0.0036) = 0.45\,\text{J}$. This becomes kinetic energy: $0.45 = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 = 0.5(0.10)v^2 = 0.05v^2$. Thus $v^2 = 0.45/0.05 = 9$, so $v = 3.0\,\text{m/s}$.

questions.question: A $55\,\text{kg}$ diver jumps from a $10\,\text{m}$ high platform. If they enter the water with a speed of $13\,\text{m/s}$, calculate the amount of mechanical energy lost to air resistance. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: Initial potential energy $PE_i = mgh = 55(9.8)(10) = 5390\,\text{J}$. Final kinetic energy $KE_f = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 = 0.5(55)(169) = 27.5(169) = 4647.5\,\text{J}$. Energy lost $= 5390 - 4647.5 = 742.5\,\text{J}$.

questions.question: A motor has a power rating of $1.2\,\text{kW}$. How long will it take for this motor to lift a $150\,\text{kg}$ load to a height of $12\,\text{m}$? (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
A cyclist exerts a constant force of $35\,\text{N}$ on the pedals while riding at a constant velocity of $8.0\,\text{m/s}$. Calculate the power generated by the cyclist.
questions.explanation: At constant velocity, the power is $P = Fv = 35 \times 8.0 = 280\,\text{W}$.

questions.question: A $2.0\,\text{kg}$ mass is attached to a vertical spring, causing it to stretch $0.15\,\text{m}$ to a new equilibrium position. Calculate the elastic potential energy now stored in the spring at this equilibrium position. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: At equilibrium, the spring force balances weight: $kx = mg$, so $k = mg/x = 19.6/0.15 \approx 130.67\,\text{N/m}$. The elastic potential energy stored is $E = \frac{1}{2}kx^2 = 0.5(130.67)(0.0225) \approx 1.47\,\text{J}$.

questions.question: A rubber band stretches $0.05\,\text{m}$ when a $10\,\text{N}$ force is applied. Assuming it obeys Hooke's law, what is the total strain energy stored when it is stretched to a total elongation of $0.15\,\text{m}$?
questions.explanation: Spring constant $k = F/x = 10/0.05 = 200\,\text{N/m}$. Strain energy stored at $x = 0.15\,\text{m}$ is $E = \frac{1}{2}kx^2 = 0.5(200)(0.0225) = 2.25\,\text{J}$.

questions.question: A $0.45\,\text{kg}$ soccer ball moving at $12\,\text{m/s}$ strikes a stationary $0.05\,\text{kg}$ bird. After the collision, the ball's velocity is reduced to $10\,\text{m/s}$ in the same direction. Calculate the final velocity of the bird (assuming it moves in the same direction as the ball).
questions.explanation: Conservation of momentum: $m_b v_{b1} + m_{bird} v_{bird1} = m_b v_{b2} + m_{bird} v_{bird2}$. Plugging in: $0.45(12) + 0.05(0) = 0.45(10) + 0.05v_{bird2}$. So $5.4 = 4.5 + 0.05v_{bird2} \Rightarrow 0.05v_{bird2} = 0.9 \Rightarrow v_{bird2} = 0.9/0.05 = 18\,\text{m/s}$.

questions.question: A $1500\,\text{kg}$ car moving at $15\,\text{m/s}$ East collides head-on with a $2500\,\text{kg}$ truck moving at $10\,\text{m/s}$ West. If the vehicles stick together after the collision, calculate their final velocity.
questions.explanation: Take East as positive. Initial momentum $p_i = 1500(15) + 2500(-10) = 22500 - 25000 = -2500\,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m/s}$. Total mass after collision $m_{\text{total}} = 1500 + 2500 = 4000\,\text{kg}$. Final velocity $v_f = p_i / m_{\text{total}} = -2500/4000 = -0.625\,\text{m/s}$, which means $0.625\,\text{m/s}$ West.

questions.question: An archer shoots a $0.12\,\text{kg}$ arrow from a $1.8\,\text{kg}$ bow. If the arrow leaves the bow at $35\,\text{m/s}$, calculate the initial recoil velocity of the bow (neglect external forces).
questions.explanation: Conservation of momentum: initial total momentum $= 0$. Thus $0 = m_{arrow}v_{arrow} + m_{bow}v_{bow}$. Solving: $v_{bow} = - (m_{arrow}v_{arrow})/m_{bow} = -(0.12 \times 35)/1.8 = -4.2/1.8 \approx -2.33\,\text{m/s}$. The magnitude is $2.33\,\text{m/s}$ in the opposite direction.

questions.question: Three resistors with resistances $100\,\Omega$, $200\,\Omega$, and $500\,\Omega$ are connected in series with a $12\,\text{V}$ battery. Calculate the current through the $200\,\Omega$ resistor.
questions.explanation: Total resistance $R_{\text{total}} = 100 + 200 + 500 = 800\,\Omega$. Current $I = V/R_{\text{total}} = 12/800 = 0.015\,\text{A}$. In a series circuit, this same current flows through all resistors.

questions.question: In a series circuit containing two resistors, the total resistance is $150\,\Omega$. If the voltage drop across the first resistor, which is $50\,\Omega$, is $4.0\,\text{V}$, calculate the total battery voltage.
questions.explanation: Current $I = V_1/R_1 = 4.0/50 = 0.08\,\text{A}$. Total voltage $V_{\text{total}} = I \times R_{\text{total}} = 0.08 \times 150 = 12\,\text{V}$.

questions.question: Determine the equivalent resistance of a $15\,\Omega$ and a $30\,\Omega$ resistor when they are connected in parallel.
questions.explanation: For resistors in parallel, $R_{\text{eq}} = (R_1 \times R_2)/(R_1 + R_2) = (15 \times 30)/(15 + 30) = 450/45 = 10\,\Omega$.

questions.question: Two resistors are connected in parallel across a $9.0\,\text{V}$ battery. The total current supplied by the battery is $1.2\,\text{A}$. If one of the resistors is known to be $10\,\Omega$, find the resistance of the other resistor.
questions.explanation: Total equivalent resistance $R_{\text{eq}} = V/I_{\text{total}} = 9.0/1.2 = 7.5\,\Omega$. For two resistors in parallel, $\frac{1}{R_{\text{eq}}} = \frac{1}{R_1} + \frac{1}{R_2}$. Thus $\frac{1}{7.5} = \frac{1}{10} + \frac{1}{R_2} \Rightarrow \frac{1}{R_2} = \frac{1}{7.5} - \frac{1}{10} = \frac{4}{30} - \frac{3}{30} = \frac{1}{30}$. Therefore $R_2 = 30\,\Omega$.

questions.question: A $5.0\,\Omega$ resistor is connected in series with a parallel combination of two $12\,\Omega$ resistors. The entire circuit is then connected to a $22\,\text{V}$ source. Calculate the total current drawn from the source.
questions.explanation: For the two $12\,\Omega$ resistors in parallel, $R_p = (12 \times 12)/(12 + 12) = 144/24 = 6\,\Omega$. Total resistance $R_{\text{total}} = 5.0 + 6 = 11\,\Omega$. Current $I = V/R_{\text{total}} = 22/11 = 2\,\text{A}$.

questions.question: Calculate the equivalent resistance of a circuit where three $30\,\Omega$ resistors are connected in parallel, and this parallel group is connected in series with two $10\,\Omega$ resistors that are themselves in series.
questions.explanation: For three $30\,\Omega$ resistors in parallel, $R_p = 30/3 = 10\,\Omega$. The two $10\,\Omega$ resistors in series give $R_s = 10 + 10 = 20\,\Omega$. Total resistance $R_{\text{total}} = R_p + R_s = 10 + 20 = 30\,\Omega$.

questions.question: A transverse wave on a string travels at $180\,\text{m/s}$ and has a wavelength of $1.5\,\text{m}$. Calculate the frequency of the wave.
questions.explanation: Using the wave equation $v = f\lambda$, we have $f = v/\lambda = 180/1.5 = 120\,\text{Hz}$.

questions.question: If the amplitude of a transverse wave is doubled, how does the energy carried by the wave change, assuming all other factors remain constant?
questions.explanation: The energy of a wave is proportional to the square of its amplitude. Therefore, if the amplitude is doubled, the energy increases by a factor of $2^2 = 4$ (quadruples).

questions.question: A train whistle emits a sound with a frequency of $400\,\text{Hz}$ as heard by a stationary observer on the platform. If the actual frequency emitted by the whistle is $440\,\text{Hz}$, determine whether the train is approaching or receding and calculate its speed. (Assume the speed of sound in air is $340\,\text{m/s}$)
questions.explanation: The observer hears a higher frequency ($440 > 400$), which means the source is approaching. Using the Doppler formula for a moving source approaching a stationary observer: $f' = f\left(\frac{v}{v - v_s}\right)$. Plugging in: $440 = 400\left(\frac{340}{340 - v_s}\right)$. Solving: $440/400 = 340/(340 - v_s) \Rightarrow 1.1 = 340/(340 - v_s) \Rightarrow 340 - v_s = 340/1.1 \approx 309.1 \Rightarrow v_s \approx 30.9\,\text{m/s}$.

questions.question: Two speakers are separated by $2.0\,\text{m}$ and are emitting sound waves in phase. An observer stands at a point that is $4.0\,\text{m}$ from the first speaker. What is the frequency of the sound if the observer is at a point of first-order constructive interference? (Assume the speed of sound is $340\,\text{m/s}$ and that the path difference is $2.0\,\text{m}$).
questions.explanation: First-order constructive interference occurs when the path difference is equal to one wavelength ($\lambda$). Here, the path difference is $2.0\,\text{m}$, so $\lambda = 2.0\,\text{m}$. Frequency $f = v/\lambda = 340/2.0 = 170\,\text{Hz}$.

questions.question: A pipe closed at one end has a length of $0.40\,\text{m}$. Calculate the frequency of the third harmonic for this pipe. (Assume the speed of sound in air is $344\,\text{m/s}$)
questions.explanation: For a closed pipe, the harmonics are odd multiples of the fundamental: $f_n = nv/(4L)$ for $n = 1, 3, 5, \ldots$. The third harmonic corresponds to $n = 3$, so $f_3 = 3(344)/(4 \times 0.40) = 1032/1.6 = 645\,\text{Hz}$.

questions.question: Two sound waves with frequencies of $440\,\text{Hz}$ and $444\,\text{Hz}$ are played simultaneously. Calculate the time interval between successive loud pulses (beats) heard by an observer.
questions.explanation: Beat frequency $f_{\text{beat}} = |f_2 - f_1| = |444 - 440| = 4\,\text{Hz}$. The time between beats is the period of the beat frequency: $T_{\text{beat}} = 1/f_{\text{beat}} = 1/4 = 0.25\,\text{s}$.
